notes.text:
A new Stronghold 3 release is available which contains an updated fix for
the OpenSSL ASN1 vulnerability.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
OpenSSL is a commercial-grade, full-featured, open source toolkit which
implements the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL v2/v3) and Transport Layer
Security (TLS v1) protocols, as well as a full-strength general purpose
cryptography library. 

The OpenSSL group found an issue in the patch that was released to fix the
previous vulnerability in the ASN.1 routines (RHSA-2002-164,
CAN-2002-0659).  The previous patch did not completely eliminate the
initial vulnerability and could lead to Denial of Service (DoS) attacks
against a server.  It has not been verified if this issue could lead to
further consequences, such as remote code execution.
notes.title: Details

notes.title: Terms of Use

publisher.issuing_authority: Red Hat Product Security is responsible for vulnerability handling across all Red Hat offerings.
publisher.name: Red Hat Product Security

document.title: Red Hat Security Advisory: openssl security update for Stronghold

notes.text: The ASN1 library in OpenSSL 0.9.6d and earlier, and 0.9.7-beta2 and earlier, allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service via invalid encodings.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

remediations.details:
We have backported the fix for the version of OpenSSL included in
Stronghold 3.  Stronghold 3 build code 3019 is now available which
includes this fix, and can be downloaded from 
http://stronghold.redhat.com/sh3/

For information on how to upgrade between releases of Stronghold 3, see 
http://stronghold.redhat.com/support/upgrade-sh3.xml
